items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from the North Sea has now reduced. There may still be standing water and debris on promenades, footpaths and roads. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high but continue to slowly fall. Since Wednesday 15/02/2023, the level at Finchdean has fallen by 0.47m. We currently do not expect any flood impacts from groundwater to be ongoing. Today (22/02/2023) and tomorrow (23/02/2023), up to 10mm of rain is forecast on each day. The weather from Friday (24/02/2023) to Sunday (26/02/2023) is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels may rise slightly in response to the rain forecast, but overall the level is expected to decrease this week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If persistent heavy rain returns in March 2023, groundwater levels could rise again and cause further impacts. If this does happen, we will issue further advice.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are high but continue to fall. Since Wednesday 15/02/2023, the level at Whitedale has fallen by 3.87m. We currently do not expect any flood impacts from groundwater to be ongoing. Today (22/02/2023) and tomorrow (23/02/2023), up to 10mm of rain is forecast on each day. The weather from Friday (24/02/2023) to Sunday (26/02/2023) is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue falling throughout this period. We continue to monitor the forecast. If persistent heavy rain returns in March 2023, groundwater levels could rise again and cause further impacts. If this does happen, we will issue further advice.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.76mAOD at 17:00 on 23/02/2023.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 38 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 23/02/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high but continue to slowly fall. Since Wednesday 15/02/2023, the level has decreased by 71cm. We currently do not expect any flood impacts from groundwater to be ongoing. Today (22/02/2023) and tomorrow (23/02/2023), up to 10mm of rain is forecast on each day. The weather from Friday (24/02/2023) to Sunday (26/02/2023) is expected to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels may rise a little (by no more than a few centimetres) for 24 hours after any recorded rain. The level will then continue to fall. We continue to monitor the forecast. If persistent heavy rain returns in March 2023, groundwater levels could rise again and cause further impacts. If this does happen, we will issue further advice.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:45pm and 3:45pm today, Thursday 23rd February. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Southend of 3.50 mAODN at 2:45pm today, Thursday 23rd February, which is 0.26m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 24th February.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Tide water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. However, there is potential for flood risk from high tides during the evening of Friday 24th February, and we will keep you informed of any changes. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to spring tides. First forecast high water is 21:00 on 22/02/23. Second forecast high water is 09:30 on 23/02/23. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates. This message will be updated Thursday 23/02/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:00pm and 3:00pm today, Thursday 23rd February. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may experience some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast, for those that use it, is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.77 mAODN at 2:00pm today, Thursday 23rd February, which is 0.37m above tide tables, wind Force 5, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 24th February.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the coast of the Isle of Sheppey and the coast from Kemsley to Seasalter as a result of the high tide expected this afternoon at 2:45pm. 
The tide will be at its highest between 2pm and 3:45pm today, 23/02/23. 
The astronomical water level forecast for the 2:45pm tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.12m AOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.48m AOD. The wind will be a force 5 North Easterly. Areas of concern include Faversham and Conyer and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
 
Once the high tide this afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier and Front Brents.

This message will be updated by 5pm today, 23/02/23.

items.description: Coast from Dartford to Allhallows
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the coast from Dartford to Allhallows as a result of the high tide expected today at 2:45pm. 
The tide will be at its highest between 2pm and 3:45pm today, 23/02/23. The astronomical water level forecast for the 2:45pm tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.12m AOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.48m AOD. The wind will be a force 5 North Easterly. Areas of concern include Royal Pier Road in Gravesend and low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths. 

Once the high tide has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Dartford Creek Barrier, Canal Basin and Queenborough Barrier.

This message will be updated by 5pm today, 23/02/23.

The tide will be at its highest between 2pm and 3:45pm today, 23/02/23. The astronomical water level forecast for the 2:45pm tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.12m AOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.48m AOD. The wind will be a force 5 North Easterly. Please be careful along beaches, low lying land nearest the sea such as promenades and coastal footpaths.
 
Once the high tide has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are operating our defences and structures at Queenborough Barrier and Front Brents.

items.description: Tidal Medway, Medway estuary and Isle of Grain
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
A Flood Alert has been issued for the Tidal Medway, Medway estuary and Isle of Grain as a result of the high tide expected this afternoon at 2:45pm. The tide will be at its highest between 2pm and 3:45pm today, 23/02/23. The astronomical water level forecast for the 2:45pm tide recorded at Sheerness will be 3.12m AOD and the forecast total water level will be 3.48m AOD. The wind will be a force 5 North Easterly. Areas likely to see impacts include Strood, Upnor and other low lying areas of the Medway Estuary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
  
Once the high tide this afternoon has passed, conditions are expected to improve from 4pm onwards. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are operating Queenborough Barrier. 

This message will be updated by 5pm today, 23/02/23.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from the Thames Barrier to Putney Bridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: City of London, Greater London, Greenwich, Hammersmith and Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea, Lambeth, Lewisham, Newham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets, Wandsworth, Westminster

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.51mAOD at 16:00 on 23/02/2023.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 38 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 23/02/2023, or as the situation changes.
